I've heard polarization explained in a significantly different way, in which this all seems like nonsense, and it's really quite simple why more light comes through when you add the inbetween oriented filters. Essentially, when light passes through a polarization filter, it becomes polarized, oriented according to the orientation of the filter. At that point, another filter oriented the same way allows the same amount of light through. A filter oriented 90 degrees to the first allows no light through. A filter oriented at a different angle, say 45 degrees, allows some light through (50% at 45 degrees), and now the polarization of the light is at that new angle of orientation. So, now the filter that's oriented at 90 degrees to the first filter is only oriented 45 degrees to the second filter. Thus it's letting 50% of the remaining light through (25% of the light passing through the first polarizing filter). The math is similar for the different angles (keeping in mind that we're using trigonometry, so 22.5 degrees gets you a lot more light than half-way between 45 and 0). This is very interesting.. but.. I have quite a simple solution to this specific problem which doesn't require quantum physics.
Imagine filter A (0° - 100%), filter B (45° - 50%) and filter C (90° - 0%).
If you have filter C right after filter A no photons will go through because it's perpendicular. If you have a filter B after filter A, some photons will go through but remember: light is also a wave, not only a particle, so the wave will be polarized on a different axis, the same axis of filter B to be exact. Now, if the photons are polarized on the B axis instead of the A one, they will not be perpendicular anymore to filter C, they are going to have a component on the C axis and therefore a change to go through and get polarized again. This is valid for any rotation.
Polarizing photons will block some of them lowering the light intensity, but considering the light wave you can polarize them by small amounts without losing much intensity, that's because with a small rotational angle the component on the original angle is very large. Basically it's better to take 99.9% for a hundred times than taking 50% one time. And if the angle is lower than 10° the percentage is already quite high.
So if you had infinite filters you could polarize the photons by 90° without blocking any of them. Obviously we cannot go to infinity but the more filters you add the less photons will be lost along the way.

There has to be a mechanical analog that might support this idea. If you had some linkages (or perhaps cams, gears, or flexures) that moved in a wavelike pattern along one plane, and were perfectly rigid perpendicular to that plane, then you could expect them to move in perfect unison and have 100% power transmission (assuming negligible friction). If you could then misalign a portion of them radially, but keep them aligned axially, then it would be like you're constraining a portion of its vertical stroke, you're virtually shrinking the height of that linkage. The amount you're shrinking it by would not be linear; it would follow a cosine function. And the amount of power you're therefore able to transmit is also limited according to that function. Energy would be lost in the form of friction. Perpendicular means the mechanism jams, with zero power transmission, equivalent to cos(90°). It makes intuitive sense, because you're moving about a circle. If you introduce more stages that are only gently tilted relative to each other, then you should see more power transmission and less mechanical resistance, in proportion to the product of the cosines of their respective angles.

Considering that these glasses can and do work as lenses for the used frequencies, they not only can interfere with the photon at each glass, but typically ARE interfering. All we are then learning is that, while we can orient the polarization from a first glass in a predictable way so that it is perfectly destructively supplementary to the polarization from a second glass, we do not actually know how each glass is individually interfering. This results in a third glass interfering in a way that abrogates the perfect destruction.

Effectively, the light is changing polarity when it passes through each glass, in such a way that we know it is polarized, but not in which direction, or how the glass itself is altering the polarity. We can then orient two polarized glasses so that we know that the combined results of interference and polarization of each result in perfect destructive supplementation, without knowing either how each is polarized or how each interferes.


This might as well be a version of the three body problem. Two bodies are predictable, each interfering with the other. Three bodies are incredibly hard, and potentially impossible, to predict.

You could also see it as a restatement of Heisenberg's uncertainty principle. You can't know exactly how an individual glass alters or polarizes the light, only what the outcome of both processes is in relation to another polarizing and altering glass, and not what the result of adding a third glass will be, since we don't actually know the objective effect of any of the individual glasses.

Ultimately, it doesn't mean that there is no "hidden variable", it means that you don't even know what variables you're working with in the first place, but have falsely assumed that you do.

When you measure a probability wave, it collapses - that is, if polarization was a certain orientation that you measured, no more funny business would happen.

However, when passed through a polarization filter, the angle is only measured to a new probability, therefore every time you filter the wave, you also collapse it to a new, displaced distribution.

Visualize it: draw an x/y axis, with 0 degrees on the left end of the X, and 180 degrees on the far right, bottom of the Y being 0y and top being 100y. Next, draw a Bell curve that begins at ~0y at 0 degrees, hits maxY ~100Y (arbitrary value) at 45 degrees and goes back down to ~0y at 90 degrees. Next, draw a second identical curve with its maxY ~100Y displaced 45 degrees, at 90 degrees on the X. The area covered by the two should be light passing through both. Next, calculate the area within the two curves, then draw a new Bell curve (on a clean graph) that has the same distance of distribution (0Y at two points 90 degrees apart) but with a new maxY so that the area of this graph equals the area of overlapping two graphs earlier. The area should btw be 50% of the area of the very first curve. Next, copy this graph and displace it 45 degrees again, same procedure as before just with a slightly lower area. The new overlapping area is the amount of light that would pass through all 3 filters, or Bell-curves, equal to 0.25 of the original.

If you instead do just the first two curves but 90 degrees apart, you'll end up with 0% of the area.

If you introduce more steps of 22.5 degrees displacement between each new filtering curve, calculating the area and redistributing it to a new 90 degrees long Bell-curve between each time, you'll see that when having gone through a total of 90 degrees change (5 filters including the first) you'll have significantly more total area in your last curve than in either of the previous experiments, about 0.522 of the original.

What were doing here, is abiding by the principle that every time we measure the polarization, in terms of probability, we also affect it, by calculation how much should have gotten through (the area of the overlapping curves) and then accepting that due to our filtering measurement this should now have a probability curve centered around the filtering polarization orientation (transforming the area back into a correct probability curve).

The Entanglement experiments can easily be explained by hidden variables without going faster than the speed of light. Concluding that faster than light travel is the only way that these entangled photons makes an enormous amount of assumptions about the topology and geometry of spacetime. Some recent work in theoretical physics (actually due to two finding a connection between two of Einstein's works known as ER = EPR - for the fact that it proposes a connection between the results described by Einstein-Rosen bridges and the Einstein-Podolsky-Rosen paradox) has suggested that entanglement may be the result of dramatic curvatures is spacetime (i.e. "wormholes" or Einstein-Rosen bridges) which allow for the seemingly "instant" communication between the entangled pairs - actually just taking a geometric shortcut. Presenting the idea that hidden-variable theories have been ruled out by these experiments is completely irresponsible and biases the younger generation towards indoctrination into a certain interpretation of quantum mechanics that is far from well supported.

This video also ignores the possibility of non-commutative probability theories offering an alternative explanation to what is going on here, which are being ever more explored in both theories of quantum gravity (e.g. non-commutative geometry and causal set theory) as well as in quantum information theory and the theory of computation (the latter of which recently answered one of the biggest unresolved questions relating to entanglement and operator theory - see the paper MIP*=RE).

The light is not perfectly polarized when you pass it through a filter as even a 10 degree tilt in a subsequent filter should enable you to block the ray completely. But as we know it doesn't, we can assume that the light leaving a filter will be polarized in a manner similar to a normally distributed probability curve with the maximum at the mean direction (in this case the angle of the filter) and decreasing as you increase or decrease the angle until certain outer limits where it diminishes completely. From the video we know that a rotation of 90 degrees on either side is required to completely block out the light so the distribution function will range from -90 degrees to + 90 degrees around the angle of polarization.
Further, another fundamental assumption made in the video is that the light is getting blocked and allows a certain polarized direction to pass. But, it is more helpful to think of the filter rather as a source emanating light with a certain polarization distribution (described previously) using the incoming light.
So when the light leaves filter A (angled at 0 degrees), it has the polarization distribution with a maximum a 0 degrees and outer limits at +90 and -90 degrees. Hence when filter C (angled at 90 degrees) is used, the light is completely blocked. However, when filter B (angled at 45 degrees) is added, the light leaving filter B will have the polarization distribution with a maximum at 45 degrees and outer limits at +135 and -45 degrees. Now, when filter C (angled at 90 degrees) is added after filter B, the distributed polarization of the light leaving filter B enables C to act as a source and the light passes through albeit very dimly. I suspect specific brightness values could also be explained using the concept of the polarization distribution and would validate this whole concept.

There is a very easy non-quantum solution to this which the video covers at 8:50.

Suppose you have filters X, Y, and Z. X and Z are perpendicular. X is polarized horizontal, Z is polarized vertical.

Case 1: X and Z are the only filters

The nonpolarized light passes through X and becomes horizontally polarized. The act of polarizing non-polarized light cuts light intensity by 50% because all non-horizontal components are removed.

Since all light is now 100% horizontally polarized, none of those can pass through the vertical filter. Thus, 0% light passes through.

Case 2: All three filters are involved, in X-Y-Z order

The nonpolarized light passes through X, cutting intensity by 50%. It then hits Y. If Y is vertically polarized, then no light will pass through, no matter what kind of filters you place after that. But the premise of this experiment is that Y is not polarized vertical (it can be polarized in any direction but vertical).

So the horizontally polarized light passes through Y. Remember the action of a polarizing filter? It polarizes the light, eliminating all components that do not match its orientation. As a result, some intensity is lost. But remember the key. The remaining light is now no longer horizontally polarized.

The filter Z is perpendicular to X. Since Y was not perpendicular to X, it by definition is not perpendicular to Z.

Therefore, any light that goes through Y will have some component that exits Z. As it exits Z, it will be dimmed further, but there will be light.

Conclusion
The key realization is that filters absolutely change the state of a photon. Think of a machine that literally grabs each photon and twists it to a new orientation. If two filters are not perfectly perpendicular, light will go through. The only way to block all light would be to have two filters that are both perpendicular and in sequence.

Easy, and intuitive way to think about it:
That Venn diagram would work, if we would talk about single photons passing through 3 filters. But it is NOT one photon passing through several filters. The basis of quantum physics is that you cannot observe a particle without changing it. Each of those filters are an observations, collapsing the quantum state of the photon.
So how you should think about it, is that at every filter, at every observation, you are effectively DESTROYING that photon, and creating a NEW one, where all the attributes are reset, according to the observations.
So it doesn’t matter if photons with a certain attributes are filtered out at the first filter. Those attributes are reset when the photons are recreated at the second filter, as those attributes are permitted by the second filter.

The same thing happens at the two-slit experiment, when we are counting photons at one slit.

1. Polarization is a property of wave optics, meaning that we describe it in terms of the electromagnetic wave model of light, not the photon model. In short, polarization can be described as the direction of the oscillation of the electronic field vector so it really is hard to describe the phenomenon using photons.
2. There are four main states of polarization: unpolarized light (most light that we encounter on a daily basis), linearly polarized light, elliptically polarized light, and circularly polarized light (a special case of elliptically polarized light).

Hence the fact that Bell's inequalities are borken in experiments does not refute 'local realist' theories. It refutes locality. In fact, Quantum Mechanics is a non-local theory, since the collapse of the wavefunction is a non-local process. First, take 2 lenses and measure the amounts that the light dims or brightens as you rotate the second lens from 0 to 360 degrees (0 degrees = 100% brightness, 22.5 degrees = 92.39% brightness, 30 degrees = 86.60%, 45 degrees = 70.71% and so on and you will see that it follows a simple sine curve. Now, when we use 3 lenses and place a second lens on top of the first at 45 degrees it reduces the light to 70.71%, then a 3rd lens on top of the first 2 at a 45 degree turn from the second (90 degrees from the first) will take the light (currently at 70.71% brightness) and reduce it again by 70.71%, resulting in a final light intensity of 50% (as seen filtered through the 3 lenses). However, what is important here is the order you place the lenses. Had we taken the middle lens (lens B) out and placed it on top of lenses A and C the final light intensity would be 0%. The reason is because if we start with lens A, then place lens C on top of it at 90 degrees, it will result on 0% brightness, so adding lens B on top of that at 45 degrees would be 70.71% of 0%, which would be 0%. A polarizing filter does more than just absorbing some of the light; whatever passes the polarizer is also polarized in the direction of the filter. The light that leaves the first polarizer is vertically polarized, and none of it can pass through the horizontal filter (cos2(90) is zero). But if it encounters a 45-degree polarizer on the way, half of it passes through (cos2(45)is 1/2) and that surviving half is now polarized at 45 degrees. When this encounters the horizontal filter, the angle with the horizontal is 45 degrees, so half of it passes through. Quantum mechanics need not be invoked, classical physics explains it just fine.

There are two problems with this explanation. The first is that the assumption that polarising filters simply block certain photons is incorrect. Polarising filters modify the polarisation of the photons that pass through, thus, a photon may not have a ‘pass B’ variable before it passes filter C, but is given that variable by filter C.

The second problem concerns the Venn diagrams at 11:40. 

The area outlined in yellow and identified as a~c (a not c) in fact consists of two sections of the Venn diagram. The first section is the intersection of circle a and circle b but is not intersected by circle c (dark yellow). This section is therefore ab~c. The second section is where circle a is not intersected by either circle b or c and is therefore a~b~c (light yellow). This area, identified as a~c, is equal to ab~c + a~b~c.

Using the same method we can recognise that the area identified as b~c is in fact ab~c + b~a~c, and that the area a~b is ac~b + a~b~c.

Substituting into Bell’s inequality expressed as:       a~c <= b~c + a~b 

the inequality can be rewritten as:  ab~c +a~b~c <= ab~c +b~a~c +ac~b + a~b~c. 

The terms:  ab~c, and a~b~c appear on both sides of the inequality and can be cancelled, 

leaving the trivial result:                                         0<= ac~b +b~a~c.

Putting the ball back at the start and rolling it down Plane A, it continues until the end of Plane A and reaches Plane C. It loses a bit of momentum from the angle change, but it now continues along Plane C! Upon reaching the end of Plane C, it reaches the 90° Plane B. It loses speed at the angle change, but does not completely stop, and continues along Plane B.

This is completely incorrect in that it is not an example of Bell's Theorem. The photons passing through a polarization filter are affected. The premise is that they are not effected by passing through the filter. If they pass through a horizontal polarization filter, half of the light passes through. If we consider a light source with a random polarization of the photon's that means that light with polarization angles at + or - 45 degrees to the polarization device must get through. But what comes out? All the photons are now polarized to the horizontal. If you hold up a vertical filter, no light passes through. If you hold up a filter at 45 degrees, behind the horizontal filter, some of the light passes through the second filter, but it's polarization has now been changed to 45 degrees. As a result some of now having a new polarization angle, (ie it has been effected by passing through the 45 degree filter) light is able to pass through the third filter which is at 90 degrees to the original horizontal filter.

This experiment just demonstrates that polarization filters are not passive devices in that they effect the polarization angle of light passing through them. You can even use specialized polarization filters to change the vibration mode of the photon itself.

My two cents for the Venn at 11:25 : let 15AB be the part of the Venn where the photon passes A but is blocked by B. And 15BC where photon passes B but is blocked by C. The region representing photons passing A and blocked at C includes less than all of 15AB plus all of 15BC. On the extreme right hand side of 15AB there is a small dark space (SDS1) inside both C (so not blocked by C) and A but outside B. On the extreme left hand side of 15BC there is a small dark space (SDS2) outside both C (so blocked by C) and A but inside B . The space inside A but outside C is 15AB+15BC-SDS1-SDS2. Removing these two small dark spaces from 15AB+15BC shows that the space in A but outside C must be less than 15AB+15BC. So when B is present the number of photons available to C for blocking is much less than 50% of photons passing through A. With B present C can block fewer so more light gets through than when B is not present.

Note that at scenario at 11:25 SDS1 is inside A so the photon can get to B where it passes on to C where it also passes. But SDS2 are photons blocked by A so never get to B (which would have passed the photon) nor to C (which would have blocked the photon).

Stop looking at it from the perspective of "they are blocked". Light refracts as it goes through filters.  Bend it a little and the light covers more area, spreading the energy over a wider area.  The angle of refraction is what you change with each filter, along with a percentage of transmission.  You are still affecting the same amount of light at all times.  Yes every material has a slight blocking effect, some light is reflected, but in filters, much of that is also refracted, changing the characteristics of a percentage of light that passes through.  Refract 45 percent of the total light, the total light hasn't changed.  Refract another 30 percent of the total light, the total light hasn't changed, but how much transmitted light you are refracting vs how much already refracted, and how that refraction refocuses already refracted light means that you will be refracting less than the last filter, or less than an average of the filters.  A 25% refraction, with a 45% refraction equates to 70%  divided by 2 which usually is only about 45% max. Add a 60% to the mix and you'll get 130, divided by 3, which is just over 43% max refraction, giving you more transmission.  Any photographer will tell you, you don't use polarizers to block light, only to subdue intensity, which means refracting some of it out of focus.  With higher iso and smaller apertures, you can damage sensors with too highly intense light.  Polarizers shift some of that light out of focus, making it less intense.  Density filters actually do reflect more light than they let pass through, only because their coating is more reflective than refractive.  Stacking these filters lets you reflect light away and reduce intensity for extremely long exposures.  High iso and narrow aperture will alow you to focus light more carefully, and you can decide on the effect you really want, without the filter over correcting the focus of your light.  Many polarizers will alter the focus of the light a bit. making it more difficult to get a clear image, though the contrast of the light values in each area of the focal plane will be much higher.

I suspect that this is similar to the double slit experiment and how having information about the wave alters it.

With just one filter the light acts as a probability wave... with a probability of some not making it through. With two filters at 90 degree angles, however, it no longer acts as a probability wave since you now know too much information about the wave. You know with 100% accuracy that all of them will be blocked. When you put the 3rd filter in between at less than 90 degrees to either one, however, you remove some of your information in regards to the light going that route. You can't know with 100% accuracy which photons will get blocked by the filter in between. And the same is true with the 2nd and 3rd filter. Thus, the light remains a probability wave throughout the journey and more light makes it through.

When you think of light as discrete photon particles passing through filters, you have to use probabllity to describe the statistical likelihood any particular photon passing through a filter. What quantum mechanics explains, however, is that the photon is manifested only at its point of contact with a measuring device. The entity that actually passes through the filter is an electromagnetic wave. The amplitudes of its electric and magnetic fields that emerge from the polarizing filter are NOT limited to just a single pair of orthogonal angles (as illustrated in the video). These amplitudes fall off gradually from their peak and reach zero only at 90-degrees from the peak angle. That explains why a 0-degree polarized electromagnetic wave is completely blocked by a second filter oriented at 90-degrees. When a third filter at 45-degrees is inserted between those two filters, it only partially blocks the 0-degree wave, and passes a wave whose amplitude peaks at 45-degrees. When this wave hits the 90-degree filter, it is again only partially blocked, with its peak amplitude rotated by an additional 45-degrees.

Bell's Theorem and quantum entanglement are real and have been unequivocally demonstrated in other experiments, BUT, and this is a HUGE BUT, i think you're making a false assumption that the filters do not alter the plane of polarization of light that passes thru.  following Occam's Razor, a FAR simpler explanation is that the filter does not simply block all photons except those vibrating in a single plane, but rather, it alters the plane of vibration so that the light exiting the filter is plane polarized, but most of those photons were initially NOT in that plane of polarization, and the percent of those that are rotated varies with the degree of initial orientation relative to the filter.  this still accounts for why two filters at right angles effectively block 99+% of the photons, and this hypothesis actually has a lot to support it experimentally, in that the amount of light that is transmitted by a single filter is FAR FAR more than would be expected if only a fraction of one percent were able to pass thru.  if the assumption that the polaroid filter simply blocks all photons except those vibrating in a single plane, rotating the second filter would not gradually reduce the transmission to zero at 90˚, transmission would sharply drop to zero with the slightest rotation of the second filter.  so while the demo is interesting, i think it is unrelated to either quantum entanglement or bell's theorem.

I'm not going to argue with your assertions, nor Bell's Theorem. But what you have described does not require quantum physics, nor does it require Bell's Theorem.

First, one can explain the three filters situation entirely using classical Electromagnetism:
Let us suppose light is an electromagnetic (EM) wave [1]
Let us suppose there are substances that only allow only the component of EM waves in a particular direction to pass through (i.e. that polarising filters exist) [2]

So, our polarising filters have an axis. After an electromagnetic wave passes through the filter, the transmitted wave has a polarisation parallel to the axis of the filter. The magnitude of the transmitted wave is the component of the incident wave that lies paralell to the axis of the filter.

So, if we have unpolarised light [3] land on a polarising filter (A), we expect the transmitted light to have a magnitude equal to half the magnitude of the incident light, and a polarisation paralell with filter A.

If we try to pass the light that exits filter A through a second filter C which has an axis perpindicular to filter A, we expect no light to pass through, as the polarisation of the light incident on C is perpindicular to C's polarisation axis. Perpendicular => No component in common.

Now, consider what happens if we add a second filter B between A and C, with a polarisation axis at 45º from the other two. The light that passes through B will have a polarisation 45º from A, and 45º from C. It will have a diminished magnitude. When this light hits filter C, it is not perpindicular to C's axis, and so some of it will pass trhough.

Q.E.D. (quod erat demonstrandum) without using QED (Quamtum Electro Dynamics)!

[1]: Maxwell's laws, which are entirely classical, allow a self-sustaninig electromagnetic wave
[2]: It's possible to make a polarising filter based entirely on classical EM, based on reflecting light at the correct angle between the correct materials
Manage

Here's the mathematical law that describes light passing through a polarising filter. Check out the wikipedia article on Polarizer for images, etc.:

Here's the mathematical law that describes light passing through a polarising filter. Check out the wikipedia article on Polarizer for images, etc.:

E_transmitted = E_incident * cos(theta_incident - theta_filter)
Where
E_transmitted is the magnitude of the electric field of the transmitted wave
E_incident is the magnitude of the electric field of the incident wave
theta_incident is the polarisation angle of the incident wave
theta_filter is the angle of the filter.
[You can choose an arbitrary origin to measure the angles from, since we just look at their difference.]

Intensity is proportional to electric field squared:
I_transmitted = I_incident * cos^2(theta_diff)

---------------------
So, consider the first situation described above (Unpolarised light incident on filter A then on filter C):
The light transmitted through A, before hitting C, will be given magnitude E_AC
E_AC = E_Incident * 1/sqrt(2) [This 1/sqrt(2) comes from the fact that for unpolarised light we integrate the formula for intensity for all possible theta_diff]

Then E_Transmitted = E_AC * cos(theta_A - theta_C) = E_AC * 0 = 0

---------------------
Now consider when we add filter B as above:
E_AB = E_Incident * 1/sqrt(2)
E_BC = E_AB * cos(theta_A - theta_B)
= E_AB * cos(45°) = E_AB * 1/sqrt(2)
= E_Incident * 1/2

E_Tr = E_BC * cost(theta_B - theta_C)
= E_BC * cos(45°) = E_AB * 1/sqrt(2)
= E_Incident * 1/(2 * sqrt(2))

And we have shown that now transmitted light (E_Tr) is non-zero.

---------------------
Finally, consider what happens if we have a large number of filters that must turn the polarisation of light 90° (N filters after the first filter).
E_Tr = E_Incident * 1/sqrt(2) * cos(90°/N)^N
We see that as N becomes very large, this tends to:
E_Tr = E_Incident * 1/sqrt(2)
or
I_Tr = I_Incident * 1/2

Once again, we have agreement with experiment without resorting to quantum physics.

Take the light that exits the black box, put it through a partially silvered mirror to split it into two beams. Send that light to your far away filters. Solid, yet transparent materials like glass are fascinating when some thought is applied to what is actually happening within a solid body that allows light to “pass through”. A solid object that can be “seen through” is not allowing photons to “pass through”, but is instead “transmitting” photons by passing energy “packets” from atom to atom in the media. A weak analogy would be the difference between a stream of water directed at a screen mesh, vs one directed at a target that activates a valve releasing another stream. The stream of water directed at a screen allows the water that misses the mesh wires to pass through, meaning that the same water molecules passing through the plane of the mesh arrive at the opposite side. This is not how light “passes” through transparent materials. The actual mechanism is more like aiming the stream at the target actuated valve; the original stream does not pass through the target, but is “expressed” through the other side as a different, yet proportional stream. A sheet of glass may appear to be perfectly “clear” to our eyes, but depending on its chemical properties, may be almost opaque to infrared or ultraviolet light. On the other side, an infrared lens may appear to be opaque to our eyes, but is almost perfectly transparent to infrared light. Therefore, light energy does not “pass through” transparent materials, but rather is “converted” to “quantum packets” whose transmissivity is affected in very different ways, depending on the medium. Like the “Newtons cradle” toy, the “ball” that impacts the mass of stationary ones causes an almost perfect transfer of energy through the row, but the ball that “pops” off of the end of the row is obviously not the same one that started the reaction. The properties of the crystalline matrices in various transparent materials also give rise to differences in reflectivity, color transmission, refractivity, scatter, and coherence. It became easier to grasp the effects of materials on quanta when the idea of transparency was divorced from the perception that the photons I observe from one side of a window are the “same” ones that entered the other side.

The deeper problem is the absence of a perfect polarizing filter. That is, we can imagine a stream of light containing a huge number of potential orientations. The filtering out of all but one orientation is impossible. In reality, the number of points on the circumference of a circle cannot be defined (infinity).

That means in reality, the difference between any one angle and the next is infinitely small (perhaps limited only by the Planck length between line segments drawn on the circumference). That is, the most perfect circle one could ever hope to achieve in physical reality is really a polygon with sides of one Planck length. That means that for any orientation of a light wave propagating at a particular angle, there is at least one angle left and right of that orientation one Planck length apart. These would effectively be the same orientation though they are actually different.

Of course, the Planck limit is more about our inability to define lengths that are smaller and not necessarily anything intrinsic to reality itself, so there could be an undefinable number of angles between one Planck length segment and the next on a circle's circumference. That would imply that there is an infinite possible orientations that will pass through what we would regard as one Planck degree, which is as perfect as a polarizing filter can hope to ever be due to the uncertainty principle and quantum effects. That is, just because half a Planck length is meaningless to us does not mean it is meaningless in reality.

The point is that though we might think 50% of the light is making it through two filters 45 degrees different, more light is getting through than we should intuitively expect because of quantum indeterminism and the physical functional limitations of polarization (the absence of actual perfection). Even if we could construct some quantum polarizing filter, where the polarization is perfect to one Planck length of angle, we have no guarantee that some wave of slightly less than that difference wouldn't also make it through. We just could not tell any difference as such waves would be functionally (though not actually) equivalent.

This is why quantum indeterminancy is apparently required for any system involved at fundamental levels like moving photons around. The fact is that it is necessary for there to be an incomplete description (the unknown variable issue in this video). The hidden variable necessary to make such systems purely deterministic is likely just something WE wish exists.

The reality that we cannot calculate is only approximated in our best methodology, which appears itself to remain necessarily incomplete. Think of it this way, a strict determinist might regard Schrodinger's cat as actually alive or dead, and that merely our lack of knowledge of the cat's state doesn't change that fact about reality. The cat is not really in both states until observed as that is absurd (a violation of the first logical absolute). In the same way, surely a light wave only has a single orientation regardless of our ignorance or inability to calculate/predict that orientation.

But reality gives us the finger by making it impossible to know such details in advance and apparently doesn't give a damn about time either (the whole super-luminal communication is merely presuppositional nonsense based on a biased view of unidirectional time). What we have to do to make sense of MANY quantum interactions is throw out such biases and let quantum entities behave as they apparently do in both directions of time.

Just look into Feynman's diagram for Beta minus decay. The whole thing doesn't work unless we presume (at least as a convention) that anti-particles are just their positive equivalents going in the opposite direction in time. Now, the $10,000,000 question is whether or not this convention reveals an underlying truth about reality or is just a convenience for our puny brains. Why should it be necessary to describe such an interaction this way if it is actually not the case? Wouldn't messing with time such that it can be reversible just to make our calculations and diagrams work be cheating if it wasn't actually something that maps to reality?

The problem with this video is they are not thinking of the lenses as transmitting the wave energy. Since the wave energy passing through a polarized lens is only transmitted on one axis, if you pass that wave through more than one lens, the total energy is multiplied by the cosine of the angle of each consecutive lens. So if you send light through one lens then another set at 45 degrees from the first, you get about 70.7 percent of the light you would get with just one filter. The cosine of a 45 is about 0.707. If you just have two lenses set at 90 degree angles, none of the energy is transmitted through. The cosine of a 90 degree angle is zero. If, however, you put a lens set at 45 degrees between two lenses set at a 90 degree angle, the amount of light that you should expect to get through is the cosine of a 45 times the cosine of a 45. This happens to be 50%. If you have three lenses set at 22.5 degrees each, you calculate the cosine of a 22.5 * the cosine of a 22.5 and you get about 0.85. This is why the as the video points out, you get 85% of the light.

If I understand it correctly, the current thinking is that there's some kind of probability distribution of states that the photon is in all at the same time. Right? And then the filter, the measurement, forces it to "collapse" into one of its probable states.

I don't think that's the case. I think the photon is flashing between a set of discrete states. Not being in those states at the same time , but rather alternating between the states, one at a time . Whether or not it goes through a given filter depends on when it hits the filter -- which state it's in at that instant. If the photon was initially unpolarized, and it hits a horizontally polarized filter, then it is initially flashing horizontal - zero - vertical - zero. (The "zero" state encodes the energy of the photon and which direction it will flash next, but it's not currently "out" in either direction.) IF it hits the filter when it's in its horizontal state or in the zero state about to go horizontal, then it will go through. IF it hits the filter when it's in its vertical state or about to go vertical, then it won't. And if it does go through, the filter takes away the vertical component -- from that point on, it's only encoded to flash horizontally: horizontal - zero - horizontal - zero. Neither of these states can make it through a vertically polarized filter, so none of them make it through filter C.

This explains "entanglement" WITHOUT requiring violation of local realism. The entangled particles are simply in sync with each other timewise as well as direction-wise. They key here is that they're going through the filters AT THE SAME TIME. So of course they will either both make it through or both not, when given the same filter at the same time -- because they're both in the same state at that time, either a state that can make it through the filter, or one that can't. Likewise, if one hits filter C at the same time as the other hits filter A, they will both either be in a state to make it through C but not A, what happens depends on what point they're both at in their (identical) phase cycling. 1/4 of the time they will both be in a state to make it through both A and C; 1/4 of the time they will both be in a state to make it through neither; 1/4 of the time they will both be in a state to make it through A but not C; and 1/4 of the time they will both be in a state to make it through C but not A.

You have to look at energy and not just time, I think, to understand how filters A and B interact. This is why wave functions work so well to describe this motion. While the photon is alternating between horizontal and vertical (and zero) flashes in time, it's also got different amounts of energy that fluctuate with time. And the entangled photons, remember, are perfectly identical, coordinated in time. To make it through the filter that's at an angle between vertical and horizontal, it has to not just be in the correct state at the instant when it hits the filter, but it also has to have enough energy to make it through in that state. (I think the energy is also (probably) quantized, by the way, but it's a lot easier to use a continuous function to represent it.) And it's the amount of time the photons spend in each combined direction-energy state that determines the proportions we see going through the filters. Of the ones that are in a state that can make it through A, 85% are also in a state that can make it through B *at that exact same time*. And vice versa. And similarly for C and B, too.

This completely explains it without requiring any kind of violation of local realism. No?

Unfortunately, this video seems to miss the key subtleties of Bell’s theorem. The part with the polarisers doesn’t really have anything to do with quantum weirdness or even light, rather projection of vectors (you would see exactly the same effect projecting the hypotenuse of a triangle).

So the polarisation projection has nothing to do with hidden variables and this is the key to Bell: since a photons polarisation can be measured, and if we can hold our local hidden variable constant (this is why it must be a local variable!), then we can sweep the hidden variable and it is no longer hidden (Or at least has some bounds). It turns out we can do experiments with very specially prepared (not all) quantum states, to show that these bounds can be broken.

Bells inequalities can be broken with classical states, however this is not nearly as interesting because it requires some nonlocal variable (such as an EM field, or waves on water) which can be measured without collapsing a wavefunction.

This is very hard to accept in our classical macroscopic view and that's why Schroedinger's cat is so popular and some geniuses like Einstein tried to preserve the deterministic view of nature, e.g. using a hidden variable theory. This video attempts to use a discrete particle model to analyze wave phenomena. As Kevin Lyon points out below, that leads to seemingly contradictory results because what actually passes through the polarizing filters are not particles, but electromagnetic waves. These waves are not comprised of discrete particles that individually have a statistical probability of passing through a particular filter, they are fields that propagate through space. The crucial difference is that unlike particles, waves can be readily superimposed into a collective wavefront without "colliding" with each other (they produce periodic interference patterns instead).

In an unpolarized light source, the polarization of superimposed waves is randomly distributed, producing a wavefront with randomly varying interference patterns. When it passes through a polarizing filter, the wavefront that emerges is polarized in a particular direction. All waves that comprised the original wavefront pass through the filter, but the intensity of each polarized wave depends on how closely its original polarity happened to be aligned with the polarizing filter. Since the filter imposes the same polarity on all emerging waves, they combine without mutual interference into a uniformly polarized wavefront.

Once the wavefront is polarized, additional filters act like valves that determine how much (intensity) of the wavefront passes through, while imposing the filter's polarity on the emerging wavefront. A filter that is rotated 90 degrees (with respect to the wavefront's polarity) is effectively "off", reducing the wavefront's intensity to zero. A 45-degree filter allows the polarized wavefront to pass through at 50% intensity. Thus, two 45-degree filters allow 25% of the polarized wavefront to pass, with a cummulative polarity of 90 degrees, whereas a single 90-degree filter would block 100% of the polarized wavefront.

Actually, this three-lenses issue is more simply explained if you use the wave model of light. Basically, when a wave of light passes through a polarizing filter, it gets twisted to the angle of the polarizer and shrunk depending on how much it was twisted. Thus, when there's only two lenses, the light out of the first filter (polarized the same way as it) shines onto a filter perpendicular to it; a filter at this angle reduces the wave to zero, so no light goes through. However, if the third filter goes in between, the wave now goes through two 45-degree twists instead of a 90-degree one, which will not reduce the wave to zero. In general, splitting a twist into multiple smaller ones increases the amount of transmission, for the same reason. The problems only ensue when you try to work this with individual particles, as described in the video.

Great video full of great explanations, and I love the collaboration with another of my favorite channels, but I wish people talking about quantum mechanics would not simplify and overstate the conclusions of Bell's research. Physics educators tend to only talk about realism and locality, without mentioning counterfactual definiteness and no-conspiracy.

Bell's research doesn't show that realism and locality don't go together - it's more complicated, the actual constraint is weaker. You can't have all of the following:

- Realism
- Locality
- Counterfactual Definiteness
- No Conspiracy

If you drop counterfactual definiteness or no-conspiracy, local realism is perfectly possible. Many Worlds for example is real, arguably local, and features no-conspiracy - it makes do with dropping counterfactual definiteness.

Here's a seminal paper on this issue from 1992: Interpretations of Quantum Mechanics, Joint Measurement of Incompatible Observables, and Counterfactual Definiteness - W. M. de Muyncko, W. De Baere & H. Martens

For those who may be a little lost, here's my attempt at explaining this a different way (at least, as far as I understand it; I hope I'm not completely wrong here!):

Basically, if you take any photon and assume that there's some way (even if we don't know what that way is) of knowing whether it would pass through each filter, then taking a sample of 100 such photons, you can calculate the percentage that would get through two of the filters (simply by multiplying the probabilities), or all three (by multiplying all three probabilities). The Venn diagram simply shows those percentages by showing each photon that would make it past each filter in your hypothetical sample.

But there's no way to make any combination of those values match with the experimental results, because any overlap between any two of those circles will cover up too much of the third circle. In other words, there's "not enough area" to overlap all the circles with a proportional amount of light that matches both the multiplication of probabilities as well as the experimental results of the actual probabilities, so one of those two can't be right. And since we observe the experimental values... we have to assume that's the correct one, and the mathematical way that assumes there are pre-existing properties of the photons that would determine their percentages at each filter? That must be wrong.

And the entanglement part simply rules out the idea that maybe there IS a property that still determines the percentages, but that property changes after a photon passes through one filter, so you can't just multiply the probabilities out. With the entangled particles, each particle only ever goes through one filter, so there is no way any properties can be changed in the process, unless somehow one particle passing through Filter A can "tell" the other particle that it's done so and alter the other particle's probability of passing through B or C. But the particles are so far from each other, and they pass through the filters at basically the same moment, so the only way for Particle One to "tell" anything to Particle 2 would be if they somehow communicated faster than light.

And so that brings us to the conclusion here: either quantum particles have no pre-existing properties that determine their behavior until they're measured (they're "non-real"), or somehow they can communicate faster than the speed of light (they're "non-local"); they can't be both.

As opposed to assuming that Quantum Objects do have Hidden Variables and doing a Proof by Contradiction based on that assumption, let's see what we can prove if we instead assume that they don't .

Again we look at Entangled particles. Let's call the polarizing filter of orientation "A" at one location "Filter A1", whereas the polarizing filter of orientation "A" at a location far away from the first one will be "Filter A2". Similarly, let's look at a pair of Entangled photons, where the member of the pair to be sent to Location 1 is "Particle p1" and the one to be sent to Location 2 is "Particle p2". We'll have p1 passing through A1 and p2 passing through A2. No other directions needed.
Now, the fact that p1 and p2 are Entangled, means that no matter how short a time passes between p1 passing through A1 and p2 passing through A2 -- even if they pass at the exact same time -- the photons still have to either both pass the filters or both be stopped by them. Similarly, regardless of how far the filters A1 and A2 are apart, p1 and p2 are guaranteed to either both path through the filters or both be stopped by them. In other words: even if [the distance between the filters] divided by [the time between the particles passing through the filters] exceeds the Speed of Light, both photons still get the same result when attempting to pass through the filters.
But hang on. We assumed that the particles wouldn't 'know' whether they would pass through a filter oriented in a certain direction until they passed through it. This means that an non-Entangled photon should have about a 50/50 chance to pass through a polarizing filter oriented in any given direction. If Entangled particles would not communicate at all, this would give a 50% chance that, if two Entangled photons were fired at filters oriented in the same direction, one photon would pass through it's filter and one wouldn't. But this is contradicted by both the Theory and the Experiment regarding Entangled particles -- two Entangled photons always either both pass or both fail to pass though polarizing filters oriented in the same direction. Thus, we have proven that Entangled particles most definitely communicate with each other, even if no Hidden Variables exist.
Furthermore, due to the fact that the similarity of the results at both locations depend neither on the distance between the locations nor the time between one photon passing through it's "A" filter and the other doing the same, this communication has to be Faster Than Light.

This is the Thought Experiment put forward by Einstein, Podolsky and Rosen, also known as the "EPR Paradox". It proves that Local Non - Realism can't explain Entangled Particles. Of course, Einstein, Podolsky and Rosen thought that the Principle of Locality was so non-negotiable that their paper proved Realism was true -- and, in that, they were mistaken; or at least premature.



As you explained in the video, the Bell's Inequality proves that Local Realism can't explain Entangled Particles either. But you CAN'T separate that result from the one learned from the "EPR Paradox". One result is meaningless unless it goes in tandem with the other. Together, the two results prove that no Interpretation of Quantum Mechanics can be consistent with experiment and still maintain the Principle of Locality. Fortunately, it turns out that this "Spooky Action at a Distance" doesn't violate the Theory of Relativity, as you can't actually communicate any information Faster Than Light through this method.

I don't quite follow- why is this such a difficult thing to explain? Maybe I'm just grossly over-simplifying the problem, but how's this for an explanation:
The light passing through a filter is 100% polarized in the direction of the filter. If a wave isn't perfectly aligned, the wave can still 'fit through', albeit with a lower amplitude, but is rotated to that filter's polarity in the process. You can prove this experimentally by placing two filters that are slightly offset from one another, and then a third filter that is aligned with the 2nd - the third filter won't block any additional light. The fact they rotate the wave is actually a very important property for how we use polarizing filters. The amplitude of the resulting wave will be the cos^2(a) of the angle between the two filters. This makes it very easy to explain this behavior both in terms of a wave, and a particle:

For a wave: The filters rotate the wave to their own orientation, so both filters combined will block less light than just the two filters. For example, 3 filters with 45° between them, will transmit 25% of the light coming through the first filter, as explained in the video. This also explains why more and more intermediate filters transmit more and more light: With the transmitted light per filter coming closer and closer to 100%, the total amount of transmitted light rises as well. In theory, with an infinite amount of polarizing filters rotated from 0° to 90°, it would be possible to rotate the light's polarization by 90° without losing any of it, because 1 * 1 * 1 * 1 ... will equate to 1.

For a particle: We can go with the explanation the video gave us that a photon will have a cos^2(a) probability of passing through the filter. If it passes through, it is also rotated to the same polarization as the filter requires. With 3 filters with 45° between them, any photons passing through the first filter will have a 50% chance of passing through the 2nd filter, and any of those will also have a 50% chance of passing through the 3rd, giving us the same 25% of the light that came through the first filter. These probabilities follow the exact same trend as the wave explanation, up to 100% of the light from the 1st filter being transmitted and just having its polarization rotated by 90°.

With all this in mind, we can easily assume that each filter simply alters the state of the light, however you choose to look at it, and that any subsequent filter decides what to do with the light based on its polarization when it gets there. There are no 'hidden variables' and there also is no need for faster than light communication. The flaw in this experiment is in the assumption stated in the first minute of the video. Specifically the statement that “all these filters do is remove light” is demonstrably incorrect. Consider the three filters A at Vertical Polarization and C at Horizontal polarization. By definition any light passing through both A and C has had its polarization shifted by 90 degrees. What this tells us is that these filters can shift the orientation of the polarization of a light beam by 45 degrees, but not by 90. Insertion of Filter B between A and C simply provides a partial polarization shift so that filter C can complete the reorientation to horizontal. No hidden variables, entanglement or other spooky action is required to explain this behavior.

Polarizing filters don't work the way you're describing. The inherent structure of the filters simply allows light that's nearly oriented with the filter through it. When they are 90 degrees off from one another nearly all light is completely misaligned with the second filter it hits so you get almost no photons passing through. However, if you place a filter between at 45 degrees between them, then the light starts getting redirected a bit (i.e. rotated to align with the middle filter) so more light is within the angle threshold of the last filter when it hits it. Adding more intermediate filters guides the orientation more gradually with each subsequent filter so less light gets blocked. This is how LCD screens work. The liquid crystal twists the light as it passes through it (much like a stack of gradually changing polarizing filters). It's like throwing a frisbee through a picket fence. If you had a stack of fences that gradually changed orientation then they would guide the frisbee progressively towards the final orientation.

There's a problem with this argument. The hidden variable doesn't have to give the same answer to "will you pass through C?" in all circumstances. The photon could have a hidden variable which tells it to pass through a sequence A B C but not A C. There is only one constraint - if the photon survives a sequence of filters then it must survive any prefix of that sequence.

Just because the photon might change its answer for filter C based on whether it went through filter B or not, doesn't mean it has not committed to that change in advance. If it is committed, then no faster-than-light communication is necessary to explain the entangled pair - both have the same commitments before becoming spatially separated.

Earlier in the video you made the point that the probability a photon passes through a filter does not depend on the history of filters the photon has passed through, only the most recent filter. It is clear that any hidden variable, λ, if it exists at all, cannot be a static parameter. In general, λ(x,t), must at least be a time-varying parameter. Indeed, this reminds us of Maxwell's Equations, which characterize the E-field as vector that varies in both x and t.

But this is where it gets both interesting and tricky. In the mathematics of Bell's derivation, he assumes that λ(x,t) ≡ λ(-x,t) for all x and t. That is, Bell assumes a common master clock, t, that governs both photons (or particles) as they speed apart in opposite directions. That's how he manages to get the presumptive hidden variable, λ, to vanish in the derivation of his inequality.

Is this a realistic assumption? Einstein reminds us that clocks separated in space do not keep identical time. In particular, their timekeeping is affected by the strength of the local gravitational field. This means that, in general, the twin photons (or particles) do not age in perfect phase-locked synchrony, and thus cannot be algebraically canceled out. There remains some residual non-zero "beat frequency" that does not vanish from the math in the derivation of Bell's Inequality. Bell's inequality would only work if the cosmos were governed by a common master clock that kept the same time everywhere and everywhen.

The violation of Bell's Inequality not only rules out static hidden variables, it also rules out any model that relies on the assumption of a common master clock that would keep the twin particles in perfect phase-locked synchrony as they sped apart.

Rather than complain about "spooky action at a distance," Einstein might have reminded Bell about "spooky time-keeping at a distance."
